bibl.title: Notes on the Yellow Fever Commission, by John J. Moran, [1940]

div1.p: Moran sends Hench extensive notes describing locations, personalities, and other details of the yellow fever experiments and commenting on the actions and attitudes of the Cuban government regarding a Lazear memorial location.

div1.head: Notes on the Yellow Fever Commission, by John J. Moran, [1940]
div1.opener:
Obviously Mr. Moran started writing this before Senora Rojas & he

div1.p:
Observation and Notes of John J. Moran on Memorandum of
Dr. Philip S. Hench of the Mayo Clinic on this Episode.
oooOooo

Par. 5: Our military intervention in Cuba, between 1898 and 1905 are
classified as follows: “The Army of Invasion” (1898); “The Army of
Occupation” (1899-1902) and “The Army of Cuban Pacification” (1905-1906).

Par. 6: Camp Columbia came into existence in July-August, 1898 and
became Columbia Barracks about July 1, 1899. In 1902, the first year
of the Republic, it became it became “Campamento de Columbia” (Camp Col-
umbia) when it was taken over by what became the nucleous of the Cuban
Army. In 1935 it became “Ciudad Militar” (de Columbia). Even today,
except in official circles, it is known as “Campamento de Columbia” or
“Columbia”. “Ciudad Militar” (Military City) as a title given to
important military garrisons in Spain, is not at all incongruos when
applied today to the Cuban garrison. The site of “Camp Columbia” was
first used by the American Army for military purposes. Prior to that, it
was used as a “Hippodrome”, for horse racing and other sporting activities.

Par. 7: Quemados, or “Quemados de Marianao” has always been a district
or section of the Municipality of Marianao and is now considered as part
of the rambling town of Marianao. It comes under the administration of
the Alcalde (Mayor) of Marianao.

“Hospital Alfonso XII” was always a military hospital. Its name
was changed by the Americans to “Military Hospital No. 1”. After the
Army of Occupation left Cuba, in 1902, its name was changed to Hospital
Calixto Garcia. A few years ago it became autonamous, with the University
of Havana, it being actually the University Hospital but being still known
as “Hospital Calixto Garcia”.

Par. 9: In your paragraphs 9 and 123, the Pinar del Rio incident is
fairly well covered. Captain Guy C. M. Godfrey, Assistant Surgeon, U. S.
Army (the son of a distinguished Cavalry officer who won the M. H. (Medal
of Honor) in the West), was Post Surgeon at Pinar del Rio Barracks. Dr.
Robert P. Cooke, Acting Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army (Contract Surgeon),
was his assistant. Major Robert E. Lee Michie, U. S. Volunteers, was
Adjutant General on the staff of General Fitzhugh Leei, Commander of
the Department of Havana & Pinar del Rio, later changed to “Department of
Western Cuba”, with headquarters in the town of Marianao (see photo of the
building occupied by him, known as “Quinta Durañona”, where I was employed
as Field Clerk at the time of the experiments).

Par. 14: What was understood between Major Reed and the other three
members of the Board to the effect that neither of them should become
subject to experimentation is a matter in which I would be guessing,
were I to express an opinion. I do not think that Major Reed ever
seriously considered it incumbent upon himself to undergo experiments.
He would not do so without authority of the Surgeon General of the Army
and I feel morally certain that such consent would not have been obtained.
For one thing, he was too advanced in years to have a fair chance of
recovery from yellow fever and for another, he was in Cuba on a mission
which would preclude any such venture on his part. I feel reasonably
sure that Dr. Carroll, far from robust at that time, would not deliberately
-- 2 --
walk into yellow fever. While younger than Major Reed by three years,
the latter enjoyed good health, while Carroll did not. It was generally
accepted that Agramonte, in common with all Cubans, was immune, it being
presumed that all natives either had the disease in mild form, in infancy,
if not born immune. Agramonte, in later years, claimed that he was no more
immune than the rest of us, having been taken to the U. S. when he was
about five years old, returning to his native country in 1898 or 25 years
later, entering the U. S. Army as a Contract Surgeon. Of the four members
of the Yellow Fever Board, therefore, Dr. Lazear was the ideal one for
experimentation. He was 34 at the time, in sound health and devoted to
research work of the exact nature which the Board was expected to invest-
igate. It may be taken for granted that the Surgeon General of the Army
would not authorize any member of the Board to experiment upon himself nor
on any of his associates and it is equally certain that Major Reed would
not officially consent to any such proposal, although, in the case of Dr.
Lazear, he might have given passive consent, knowing that he was physic-
ally sound and would stand a good chance of surviving a possible attack of
yellow fever. Had Dr. Lazear pulled through, I am morally certain that
his case would have been properly made of record as experimental rather
than accidental. Any hint dropped by Dr. Agramonte to that effect should
carry due weight. He and Dr. Lazear were classmates and friends, both
graduating in medicine at Columbia University in 1892.

Pars. 15 and 16: Major Alexander N. Stark, commanding the Post Hospital
at Columbia Barracks, informed me, after the death of Dr. Lazear, that he
sat next to him at dinner, at the Officers' Mess, the night before Dr.
Lazear came down with yellow fever and that the latter complained of an
aching body and slight fever; that he (Stark) advised him to go lightly
on food but ate a hearty dinner just the same, stating that he had a good
appetite, having spent the day at Las Animas Hospital where he had a light
lunch. The following morning he had a high temperature and in seven days
he breathed his last. Major Stark opined that his hearty meal on the eve
of his attack was instrumental in lessening his chances of recovery. Dr.
Stark ventured no opinion as to whether his case was accidental or experi-
mental. With all due respect to any opinion expressed by Dr. Agramonte,
as recollected by his daughter, I very much doubt if Dr. Lazear was bitten
prior to September 13th. He was treated at the Post Hospital and was
buried, I believe, near Camp Columbia. As to when his remains were dis-
interred and shipped to the U. S., I do not know. Full details can be
given by his widow, I imagine, as to dates and definite resting place.
General Kean may know Mrs. Lazear's address. Dr. Carroll was treated at
the Post Hospital, Columbia Barracks and convalesced there.

Par. 22: I do not recall the names of others than the five original vol-
unteers, viz: Dr. Cooke, Folk, Jernegan, Kissinger and myself, who took
up residence at Camp Lazear on date of its inauguration. We had a cook,
kitchen police and guards, but I do not recall the names of any of them.

Par. 23: The “Infected Clothing Building” was ready when we occupied Camp
Lazear but sufficient soiled clothing was not available until about ten days
(continued on sheet 3)
ooo0ooo
NOTE: You will recall that Major Stark was my protector and preceptor. I
worked with him in the operating room and he was the first to suggest to me
that I should study medicine at his Alma Mater, the University of Virginia.
-- 3 --
after we took up residence at the camp. As near as I can recollect, the
nurse who took care of Kissinger and myself was a Mrs. Gillan. I think she
succeeded a Miss Warner, or it may have been Mrs. Warner. I do not know if
she is still alive. In addition to Mrs. Gillan, two or three Hospital
Corps men were on duty with her, but she had charge of the ward. We had
as roustabout and ward orderly, one Gustaf Eric Lambert (No. 22 on General
Truby's photo of the Hospital Corps Detachment. I think he is still alive
and it may well be that General Kean, Kissinger or Andrus could give you
his address. Last I knew of him, he was living in Chicago.

Par. 27: Building No. 2 was completed before December 21 but was not
provided with the requisite number of mosquitos until that date. I do not
know the date work was started on it nor do I remember the two men, by
name, who slept on the mosquito-free side for 18 nights.

Par. 28: The blood injection was given to me at the laboratory (the old
operating room) and it was taken from an experimental case. Major Reed
personally requested me to take the test and accompanied me until it was
all over. Who actually gave me the injection, I do not remember, but
it was not Major Reed. Principally engraved in my memory and still stick-
ing out like a sore thumb was my concern as to the purity of the blood
but Major Reed assured me that I need have no fear on that score; that a
second attack of yellow fever was all I had to fear. I had no fear of
that.

Par. 29: After Señora Rojas and myself agree as to the site of Camp Lazear,
I shall mark on the map and have photographed what WE THINK might have been
the site or part of the site. I think, however, that the high ground of
which you took snapshots and from there down to the shack, with the culti-
vated ground where you took a picture of me, with another in which appear
Mrs. Hench, yourself and your humble servant, might have been a part of
Camp Lazear. The latter pictures were taken by the photographer, the snap-
shots with your own Kodak. The trees do not fit any pictures we have of
Camp Lazear and the two trees shown in same near the entrance to the Camp.
From Hospital Militar to “Quinta San José” (gate), by the shortest route,
the distance is 2 kilometers and to the high ground referred to above, the
distance is 2.5 kilometers, respectively, a mile and a quarter and a little
over a mile and a half. The measurements were taken by speedometer.

Par. 32: Your directions for reaching Camp Lazear are OK, as near as I
can see. I could not say if the original tract taken over by the U. S.
Army has been added to or not, but I think it has, especially in the
direction of the Military Aviation Camp, marked AERODROMO on the Military
map. “Boquette” Road is more than likely a local name and I do not find
it on any map in my possession. The present Military Hospital is now
officially known as HOSPITAL GENERAL “ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE” (The Aristides
Agramonte General Hospital), the group consisting of eight buildings, the
principal of which is the “Clinica 4 de Septiembre”, the latter being a
new building and the rest new or remodeled and modernized under the new
Cuban Army. Each building has a separate name but the entire group is
known as indicated above. “Linea Paradero” would mean a way-station or
“Paradero”, where tickets are not sold. The term “Linea Paradero” is not
generally used, that I know of. The first word means “Line” and the
second “Stopping Point” or waystation. With reference to the “Framboyan”
trees on the “Finca San José” site, I am morally certain that the one we
were looking at could not be the one shown on the 1900-1901 pictures of
Camp Lazear. The limb you had cut off the tree on the false site, after
drying and testing a section of same, was declared unworkable for any form
-- 4 --
of souvenir, such as you mentioned while we were at the Souvenir Shop
in “Plaza de la Catedral” (Cathedral Plaza). I am sorry about this for
I know you had calculated on converting the wood from one of these trees
into souvenirs. I know you will be disappointed, but I am sure you
would also be disappointed in anything that could be made from Framboyan
wood. It happens to be one of the woods of Cuba good for nothing but
firewood and not very good for even that.

“Boquette” Road is not generally known as such and not shown on
any map available to me. I now note what you mean by “Linea Paradero”.
I see where you got it from. It is shown on Pogolotti's plan of the
“Reparto Padre Zamora”. Properly read, it should be “Linea Santa Isabel”
and the “Paradero” in between "Linea and “Sta. Isabel” means that the
“Carnino” station, named after Pogolotti's mother, is the way station
just as you turn into the so called road to the false Camp Lazear. As you
know, this line is not being used any more. The track is practically covered with
with weeds just now.

Unless the Cuban authorities really meant what they stated when
Colonel Hume was here in September,
1936, and the false Camp Lazear was “discovered”, there is but little
reason for dwelling too much now on the error that was made then. It
should be made clear, however, in your paper that the error might never
have been discovered had you not visited Cuba. It is due to your
initiative and your persistency in following up the matter which have
led to the discovery of the real location of Camp Lazear. On the other
hand, it would be most appropriate to have some form of memorial on the
false site, property of the Cuban government, I believe, since that site
is not lacking in historical interest. I quote from a very recent letter
from General Kean, in this connection: “I have had a lot of correspondence
with Dr. P. S. Hench. It is a most interesting story how he with your
assistance showed the Cubans that they had located Camp Lazear in the wrong
place. Where they have located it and bought the land for a monument is
where the yellow fever cases were treated in a temporary ward. I remember it
well for it is where I was treated when I had yellow fever in June, 1900
and Major Reed came to see me there. It is an appropriate place for a
monument to Lazear, BECAUSE HE DIED THERE, but it certainly is not the
location of the experimental camp where the Finlay theory was demonstrated
to be true by the Reed Commission, and which was named after Lazear but had no
other association with him. That camp was on the Rojas farm, a mile to the
east of there (actually, 1 1/4 miles to the main entrance to the “Finca San José”).
I think it is proper always to speak of the transmission of yellow fever by
mosquitoes as THE FINLAY THEORY which gives that dear old man the credit which
shoud be his.”" End of quote.

apparently
written before the
discovery of the
Rojas book.

Par. 40: According to the written record left by Dr. Ignacio Rojas which I
saw a few days ago, it would appear that the contract for rental of the camp
site was made by Dr. Echeverria, whom General Kean will recall
and whom I remember as local Sanitary Officer for Quemados and Marianao. My
friend, Charles Parker, was his Chief Clerk. It will also appear from the
records and books of Dr. Rojas that a regiment of Volunteers from one of the
Carolinas had been stationed there or rather had had their camp there, at one
time. When I was transferred to Columbia Barracks, all the volunteer troops
had left that post, the 7th U. S. Cavalry, under command of Colonel Baldwin,
being the principal unit. Col. Baldwin was in command of the entire post.
It is, of course, possible that Dr. Agramonte first spoke to Dr. Rojas about
the Camp Lazear site, Dr. Echeverria signing the contract with Dr. Rojas. You
will read all about this in the copied material that Miss Rojas will turn over
to Mrs. Phillips for translation and typing.

Par. 51: With reference to the last three lines of this paragraph (bracketed).
I do not think the invitation would be advisable. I am afraid it would not
suit him.

Par. 53: A “Finca” means a farm of 50 to 100 acres of land. From 150 acres up
it might be known as an “Hacienda”. When reduced to the present acreage of
“Quita San José”, or even half of it, it would no longer merit the title of
“Finca”. When most of the “Finca San José” was sold, the family changed the
name of the mansion and the ground still owned by them and walled off to
“Quinta San José”. A “Tejar” is a brick or tile factory.

Par. 59: Principally through my fault, we allowed Zunzunegui (pronounced Zoon-
zoon-eggy to slip through our hands. This was due to the fact that he remarked
that the Americanos used to pay $2.00 a head for people who would permit them-
selves to be bitten by mosquitoes. Within the past week, howver, this man
looms big in our investigations and his rediscovery is intimately connected
with the “discovery” of Dr. Rojas' old account books and the lease for exploit-
ation of the limestone quarries made between Dr. Rojas and Zunzunegui's father,
which included the use and occupancy of Buildings No. 1 and No. 2. After the
lease became effective, Zunzunegui Senior and his family moved into Building
No. 1 and his son (Julian) lived in that little shack from that time until
1936. After he married, 21 years ago, he and his wife lived in the shack and
all three of his children were born there. I have made notes on the photo-
graphs taken yesterday (Saturday), including on of Z. and his family, which
give additional details about him. Without a shadow of a doubt, he is more
familiar with the physical changes and transition of the “Finca San José” than
any other person that I know of today. As I have prevously stated, the good
Señora Rojas did not visit the part of the farm in which the Camp was located
in many years. Stone and earth was excavated from the land with but little
realization on her part that it was in its present honeycombed state, with a
limestone quarry on one side and a combination rock and brick clay quarry
on the other side.

Par. 69: Would suggest you deal carefully with this old Spanish medico. He
was willing to talk frankly to you but I doubt very much if he would be will-
ing to to be equally frank on paper and over his signature. In a conversation
with Miss Cabrera, she doubted very much if it would be wise or expedient for
him to make his statements about Finlay a matter of record. Personally, I do
not believe that the book he talked about will be published during his life-
time, nor after his death for the matter of that. I suggest that you soft
pedal the statements he made about Finlay. The old chap might get himself
into very hot water and I am sure you would not like that.

Par. 72: The title should read “Secretary of Sanitation” rather than “Health”.
In Spanish it would be properly “Secretario de Sanidad y Beneficencia” and
translated it would be Secretary of Sanitation and Beneficence, but the
last word in the title may be left out in your paper.

Par. 79: The name of the nurse should read Miss Clara L. Maas, the surname
having but one “s”.

Mistake-

of Oct 12, 1940

Par. 81: I am sure that Dr. Ramos and the other doctors who claimed their
site as the genuine one no longer think so. In a conversation with Mrs.
Phillips she informed me that Mr. Pogolotti had told her that the author-
ities sent a man to wipe out the sign and when I took a picture of it some
days ago. I noticed that the lettering had been erased. Evidently the job
was not very well done. The sign, as you can see by my Photo No. 10, has
-- 6 --
not been taken down. Pogolotti added that the Cuban authorities had tacitly
admitted their error. With the new evidence now within your reach, which I
propose to make known to Dr. Ramos as soon as I can “catch up” with him, it
would be folly for them to stick to their claims. So far, they know nothing
about the new evidence. After all, it is not a capital sin to err in good
faith, in such a matter, and after the lapse of so many years, but it would be
if they should pretend to stick to it, especially after the real site of Camp
Lazear is discovered. I am personally in accord with General Kean that we
should all bend our efforts to the end of having the Cubans build their park
or other form of memorial to Dr. Lazear and his associates on the site of
the tent ward in which he died. I have no doubt you could exert a healthy
influence on Dr. Ramos & Company in such a matter. From now on, I imagine
they will have a wholesome respect for you and you are sufficiently broad-
minded and big-hearted to overlook the hostility displayed towards us when we
broke the news to them that they had placed Camp Lazear where it never was.
I take it that YOUR MAIN OBJECT was and is to reconcile the American and
Cuban points of view with reference to Reed and Finlay, giving to each his
proper share of the credit and glory. It would serve no good purpose to
antagonize them by placing too great an emphasis on their error in falsely
locating Camp Lazear. After all, they may have erred in good failth, but
they were lax in consulting those who could inform them better, or rather
failing to consult them. The Cubans, as you may or may not know, are very
sensitive. I think this fault is universal when the people of a small
nation begin to compare themselves with those of a nation as powerful and as
progressive as ours, for instance. At heart, however, the percentage of
Cubans who do not like us and admire us is very small. The ingrates, mostly
COMMUNISTS, are the exception. I want you to know that, personally, I do
not fear any reprisals which might fall to my lot through my share in the
discovery of their error. Furthermore, the fact that the Cubans have honored
me with the Finlay Order or Medal does not change my opinion of the glory to
which I have always considered as pertaining to Major Reed. Very largely
due to General Keen's opinion in the premises, I have revised my opinion of
Finlay and very much in his favor, but I have never revised my opinion of
Major Reed. To me, Major Reed was THE SOUL of the episode which led to THE
CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER.

Par. 86: We met in the building of the “Consejo Corporativo de Educacion,
Sanidad y Beneficencia” (Corporate Council of Education, Sanitation & Benfi-
cence).

Par. 101 to 104: I am afraid I cannot add more on this matter than is
covered by my observations on Paragraphs 14, 15 and 16 (Page 2).

Par. 115: The space (or at least much of it) occupied by the volunteer
regiments was converted into a corral for horses and mules, as near as I
can recollect.

Par. 116: I must admit here that I am “stumped” with reference to the
bridge across the railroad track. As suggested in another paragraph,
Gustaf Eric Lambert, who had charge of the “Disinfection Plant” could give
particulars on both. He remained in Cuba until the Americans cleared out
entirely (1902), I believe. I bow to General Keen's recollections in
this connection. If I crossed any bridges to get to the hospital, after
my recovery from yellow fever, I have forgotten all about it. This covers
any remarks I could make about Paragraph 118.

Pars. 122 to 127, inclusive: I think a veil should be drawn on the
personalities mentioned here, one of whom is still alive. The Agramonte-
Hemmetr correspondence, if published, would add nothing to the glory of
the Yellow Fever Board as a whole, I am sure. C's effort at usurpation
would not entitle him to have his name used in any sentence or paragraph
wherein the name of REED appeared. Dr. Cooke was young and inexperienced,
much more especially in differentiating between Pernicious Malaria and
Yellow Fever. As a matter of fact, few American medicos present in Cuba
at that time had had experience with yellow fever and other trpoical
diseases. It was an unfortunate incident, nothing more.

LAS ANIMAS HOSPITAL: The site and the buildings, I believe, was a Spanish
Camp originally and was converted into a hospital only a short time before
the American Army landed in Cuba. A hospital known as “Los Angeles” was
abandoned and all its equipment was sent to the original “Hospital Las
Animas”. Twice, it was used as a municipal hospital and twice as a military
hospital. In 1899, General Wood, Military Governor, had it converted into
a Military Hospital. In November of the same year, it was used as a
Municipal Hospital and “Los Angeles Hospital's” equipment and utensils
transferred to it. While the record is not very clear, it was at this time
that it was baptized “Hospital Las Animas”. In January, 1900, it became a
a Military Hospital once more. A Military Order of the Governor turned it
over to the Department of Sanitation on September 7, 1900. The latter
Department then undertook to convert it into a real hospital where infectious
and contagious cases, of a nature dangerous to public health, could be treated
and/or placed under observation. Even to this day, it is the only hospital
used for the general purposes indicated above. The hospital grounds is
about fifty acres. Used by the Engineer Corps of the Spanish Army, originally,
it gradually changed into an isolation camp and eventually into a hospital.
From Barnett.

IN CONCLUSION: In order to get this to you so that it may serve your
purpose in time, should there be any notes of value in it, I am sending it
to you today by AIR MAIL, with 27 additional photographs. I will again
go thoroughly over your letters and YOUR MAIN PAPER, as I must have missed
a numbser of items. If I find that I can make appropriate reply to any-
thing I have overlooked, I will send you an additional memorandum between
now and the 20th, the date I expect to leave for God's Country.
